P.title: Will the Second Amendment of the United States Constitution be amended or repealed before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025, the Second Amendment is repealed, amended, or modified in any way through the proceduce in Article Five of the US Constitution

Q_given_P.title: Given that the Second Amendment of the United States Constitution is amended or repealed before 2025, will the United States drop below a 7 in the Democracy index by 2040?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if the Second Amendment is not amended or repealed before 2025. If the Second Amendment is amended or repealed before 2025, this question will resolve YES if at any point before 2040 the United States scores below a 7 in the Democracy Index, and NO if it does not. If the Democracy Index becomes defunct before 2040, the question will resolve ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will the Second Amendment of the United States Constitution be amended or repealed before 2025 AND will the United States drop below a 7 in the Democracy index by 2040?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) At any time between January 1, 2019, and January 1, 2025, the Second Amendment is repealed, amended, or modified in any way through the procedure in Article Five of the US Constitution. b.) At any point in time before 2040, the United States achieves a point lower than 7 in the Democracy Index. Resolves NO if either or both do not occur. If the Democracy Index becomes defunct any time before 2040, the question will resolve ambiguously.

P.title: Will Tesla become the largest car company in the world (by sales) before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Tesla Motors is the largest car producer in the world at any point before January 1, 2035, according to global car sales data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers.
If data from OICA is not available during this period, Metaculus may select an alternative credible source of data, or resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion

Q_given_P.title: Given that Tesla becomes the largest car company in the world by sales before 2035, will Volkswagen Group produce fewer than 22 million electric vehicles by 2030?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if Tesla does not become the largest car producer in the world at any point before January 1, 2035, according to global car sales data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers or an alternative credible source selected by Metaculus if OICA data is not available. If Tesla meets this condition, then the question resolves YES if Volkswagen Group has produced fewer than 22 million fully electric vehicles based on the MEB platform or its successor by the end of 2029, and NO otherwise. The count includes only fully electric vehicles and considers significant changes in Volkswagen Group’s subsidiaries that could affect production numbers.

P_and_Q.title: Will Tesla become the largest car company in the world by sales before 2035 AND will Volkswagen Group produce fewer than 22 million electric vehicles by 2030?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) Tesla Motors becomes the largest car producer in the world at any point before January 1, 2035, according to global car sales data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers or an alternative credible source selected by Metaculus if OICA data is not available. b.) Volkswagen Group produces fewer than 22 million fully electric vehicles based on the MEB platform (or a possible successor) by December 31, 2029. Only fully electric vehicles count towards this number. If significant changes occur in Volkswagen Group’s subsidiaries (adding or removing subsidiaries that had a >100k unit production in the previous year), the question resolves as ambiguous. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Starlink conduct an IPO before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This will be judged according to reports in the Wall Street Journal, Bloomberg, New York Times or Washington Post posted to the discussion below. If Starlink does not go public by 2030-01-01 00:00 UTC, the question resolves negatively

Q_given_P.title: Given that Starlink conducts an IPO before 2030, will a S&P500 tech boom surpass the dotcom bubble for one quarter or more before 2025?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if Starlink does not conduct an IPO before 2030. If Starlink does conduct an IPO before 2030, this question will resolve as Yes if the average sector weighting of the IT industry of the S&P500 surpasses 30% for either a three consecutive month period or a 90 consecutive days period, before the end of 2024, according to the current weightings of the SPDR S&P 500 ETF. Resolves No otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will Starlink conduct an IPO before 2030 AND will a S&P500 tech boom surpass the dotcom bubble for one quarter or more before 2025?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur: a.) Starlink conducts an IPO before 2030-01-01 00:00 UTC, as reported by the Wall Street Journal, Bloomberg, New York Times, or Washington Post. b.) The average sector weighting of the IT industry of the S&P500 surpasses 30% for either a three consecutive month period or a 90 consecutive days period, before the end of 2024, according to the current weightings of the SPDR S&P 500 ETF. The question resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority.

Q_given_P.title: Given that a Democrat wins the 2024 US presidential election, will any state refuse to certify their election results by the "safe harbor" deadline?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if a Democrat does not win the 2024 US presidential election. If a Democrat wins, this question will resolve YES if any state (or DC) does not certify their results by the "safe harbor" deadline of December 10th, 2024, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election AND will any state refuse to certify their election results by the safe harbor deadline?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur: a.) a candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election, and b.) any state (or DC) does not certify their results by the "safe harbor" deadline, which for the 2024 presidential election will be December 10th. The question will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority.

P.title: Will the US Supreme Court change its membership size before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the US Supreme Court officially changes its regular number of sitting justices above or below 9 members at any point between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2050.
Expected vacancies and arrivals of justices (retirements, deaths, and absences for health reasons) are not sufficient to resolve the question

Q_given_P.title: Given that the US Supreme Court changes its membership size before 2050, will Republicans win control of the US House of Representatives in 2024?
Q_given_P.body: This question will resolve as N/A if the US Supreme Court does not officially change its regular number of sitting justices above or below 9 members at any point between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2050. If the condition is met, then the question resolves as follows: Resolves true if Republicans win 50% + 1 or more seats in the US House of Representatives in 2024. Resolves false if Democrats win 50% + 1 or more seats. If neither of those parties wins 50% + 1 or more (e.g., an unaligned 3rd party wins seats), then the question resolves ambiguously. Independents who caucus with the Republicans will be counted as Republicans; likewise, independents who caucus with Democrats will be counted as Democrats. Note: If the total number of seats in the US House changes, then the number needed for a majority changes with it.

P_and_Q.title: Will the US Supreme Court change its membership size before 2050 AND will Republicans win control of the US House of Representatives in 2024?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) The US Supreme Court officially changes its regular number of sitting justices above or below 9 members at any point between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2050. Expected vacancies and arrivals of justices (retirements, deaths, and absences for health reasons) are not sufficient to resolve the question. AND b.) Republicans win 50% + 1 or more seats in the US House of Representatives in the 2024 elections. Resolves NO if either of these conditions is not met. If neither the Republicans nor the Democrats win 50% + 1 or more seats in the US House (e.g., an unaligned 3rd party wins seats), then the question resolves ambiguously. Note: Independents who caucus with the Republicans will be counted as Republicans; likewise, independents who caucus with Democrats will be counted as Democrats. If the total number of seats in the US House changes, then the number needed for a majority changes with it.

P.title: Fewer than 375M in extreme poverty by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
In September 2015, 193 world leaders adopted the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and called for a “data revolution” to enhance accountability in measuring the progress towards their fulfilment. The SDGs have 17 goals of which the first is “To end poverty in all its forms everywhere by 2030”.
Extreme poverty is defined as living on less than $1.90 a day, measured in 2011 Purchasing Power Parity prices. Currently, around 630M people (roughly 8%) live in extreme poverty worldwide. According to World Bank Data, extreme poverty has been declining by roughly 1% per year since the 1980's. However, there is evidence that the decline in global extreme poverty has been slowing.
A 2018 study by Cuaresma et al. on the poverty paths of developing countries projects worldwide poverty rates ranging from 4.5% (around 375 million persons) to almost 6% (over 500 million persons) in 2030.
Will we see fewer than 375M in extreme poverty by 2030?
This question resolves positively if there are fewer than 375M in extreme poverty in any year up to (and including) 2030. For this question we will refer to the data by the World Bank, and if this is unavailable, some other database listed on the data sources page.

Q_given_P.title: Given that there will be fewer than 375 million people in extreme poverty by 2030, will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if there are 375 million or more people in extreme poverty by 2030. If the condition is met (fewer than 375 million people in extreme poverty by 2030), then this question resolves YES if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true: Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory, or two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory. Resolves NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be fewer than 375M in extreme poverty by 2030 AND a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
P_and_Q.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: a.) There are fewer than 375 million people living in extreme poverty in any year up to and including 2030, as defined by living on less than $1.90 a day measured in 2011 Purchasing Power Parity prices, according to World Bank data or another database listed on the data sources page. b.) There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory, or two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will a US Census in 2070 or earlier show a decline in population?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a Census conducted before 2071 shows a drop in US population over the previous Census, according to official statistics from the United States Census Bureau. If the Census Bureau changes its name or merges into another entity, those statistics will be used instead

Q_given_P.title: Given that a US Census conducted before 2071 shows a decline in the US population, will there be a 'World War Three' before 2050?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if no US Census before 2071 shows a decline in population. If the condition is met (a Census before 2071 shows a decline in US population), then this question resolves YES if, between January 1, 2019, and January 1, 2050, there is a military conflict involving countries representing at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year the conflict is ongoing, and at least 10 million people (civilians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict. Resolves NO otherwise. Sources for PPP may include the IMF, World Bank, United Nations, or CIA.

P_and_Q.title: Will a US Census in 2070 or earlier show a decline in population AND will there be a "World War Three" before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:
1. A Census conducted before 2071 shows a drop in US population over the previous Census, according to official statistics from the United States Census Bureau. If the Census Bureau changes its name or merges into another entity, those statistics will be used instead.
2. At any time between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050, both of these conditions are true:
   a. There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing.
   b. At least 10 million people (civilians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict.
Fine Print for condition 2:
   - PPP will be determined from the following sources, in order of precedence: IMF, World Bank, United Nations, CIA.
   - [2022-03-24]: Edited to clarify that "world GDP" will be determined in PPP for condition 1.
   - [2021-11-24]: Edited to clarify the time constraints.
   - (Edit 1/16/19 to remove third "described as WWIII" criterion.)
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the number of deaths from antibiotic-resistant infections per year double by December 31, 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
In 1928, biologist Alexander Fleming discovered - by accident - that where the Penicillium mould had grown on a petri dish the bacteria nearby had been killed. This was due to a chemical the mould secreted, which he named "penicillin" - the antibiotic we know and love today.
Since the discovery of penicillin, antibiotics have saved hundreds of millions of lives and become an essential part of modern medicine.
But they're getting less effective. Repeated use has led to the existence of resistant strains of bacteria, which are immune to the effects of multiple different antibiotics. This has been described as a "serious, worldwide threat to public health" by the WHO.
In 2013 the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported that over 23,000 people died each year from antibiotic-resistant infections in the US. More recent data on their website suggests the figure is more like 37,000.
At any point before the end of the calendar year 2025, will the CDC or another credible source report that at least 70,000 people die annually from antibiotic-resistant infections in the US?

Q_given_P.title: Given that by December 31, 2025, the number of deaths from antibiotic-resistant infections per year has doubled to at least 70,000 in the US, will lab-grown complex vital organs have been used successfully in humans before 2025?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the number of deaths from antibiotic-resistant infections per year has not doubled to at least 70,000 in the US by December 31, 2025. If the condition is met, then this question resolves YES if before January 1, 2025, any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney, or lung. All transplantations need to be considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation. For the purposes of this question, 'lab-grown' includes organs cultivated inside a living organism so long as the organs are not naturally occurring; that is, not merely an organ taken from a non-human and implanted in a human without there having been substantial bioengineering involved to alter the harvested organs.

P_and_Q.title: Will the number of deaths from antibiotic-resistant infections per year double by December 31, 2025, AND will lab-grown complex vital organs be used successfully in humans before 2025?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) At any point before the end of the calendar year 2025, the CDC or another credible source reports that at least 70,000 people die annually from antibiotic-resistant infections in the US. b.) Before January 1, 2025, any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney, or lung, and all transplantations are considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation. For the purposes of this question, 'lab-grown' includes organs cultivated inside a living organism so long as the organs are not naturally occurring; that is, not merely an organ taken from a non-human and implanted in a human without there having been substantial bioengineering involved to alter the harvested organs. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030.
Fine Print
The EU has updated its goals under the Paris Agreement, but this question will use the original goals in place at the time the question was written, specifically the three below.
40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, compared to 2019
At least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy
At least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections

Q_given_P.title: Given that the European Union meets its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty, will there be a European Army before 2032?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: This question will resolve as Yes if a credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030. The goals include a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, at least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy, and at least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2032, there is legislation passed in at least 5 European countries (including one of France, Germany, UK) which makes provisions for an army consisting of units from multiple countries. Senior levels need to be staffed by officers from a range of countries, and the army needs to be planned to be an "Army" with at least 30,000 soldiers and report to a supranational organization that is specifically European.

P_and_Q.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty AND will there be a European Army before 2032?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) A credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030. The goals include a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, at least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy, and at least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections. AND b.) Before January 1, 2032, there is legislation passed in at least 5 European countries (including one of France, Germany, UK) which makes provisions for an army consisting of units from multiple countries, with senior levels staffed by officers from a range of countries, planned to be an "Army" with at least 30,000 soldiers, and reporting to a supranational organization that is specifically European. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Climate change geoengineering, defined by the United Kingdom’s Royal Society as “the deliberate large-scale manipulation of the planetary environment to counteract anthropogenic climate change” (Shepherd et al. 2009). Geoengineering involves the removal of greenhouse gases from the atmosphere, or attempts at reflecting more energy away from the planet to counter warming (Markusson et al., 2013). Geoengineering is often presented as a complement, and sometimes alternative, to climate mitigation and adaptation.
There are serious and complex governance issues which need to be resolved if geoengineering is ever to become an acceptable method for moderating climate change. It would be highly undesirable for irreversible global geoengineering to occur before appropriate governance mechanisms are in place. The Royal Society has published a set of geoengineering governance principles, known as The Oxford Principles, which aims to guide the collaborative development of geoengineering governance, from the earliest stages of research, to any eventual deployment. These principles are:
Principle 1: Geoengineering is to be regulated as a public good
Principle 2: The public should participate in geoengineering decision-making
Principle 3: Geoengineering research and results should be publicly disclosed
Principle 4: There should be independent assessments of the impacts
Principle 5: governance systems should be developed before geoengineering methods are deployed
As of September 2019, two geoengineering bills and one resolution have been introduced in Congress. These bills are the following:
Geoengineering Research Evaluation Act of 2017. This bill recommends a research agenda for advancing understanding of albedo modification strategies that involve atmospheric interventions, such as cloud modification; and a report that provides specific guidance on the governance mechanisms for the proposed research agenda.
American Clean Energy Leadership Act of 2009. This bill requires the Secretary of Energy to establish an Advisory Committee on Geosciences and Geoengineering Education to advise the Secretary in education and training in the subsurface geosciences and engineering.
Neither the Geoengineering Research Evaluation Act of 2017 nor the American Clean Energy Leadership Act of 2009 became legislation. So far, the U.S. has not enacted legislation that are explicitly related to geoengineering.
Will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024?
This questions resolves positively if a geoengineering bill that is introduced in the House of Representatives and/or the Senate is subsequently enacted as legislation (by being signed by the U.S. president, or through other means) before or on 31/12/2024. For the purpose of this question, a geoengineering bill is any bill reported by the relevant Congress website search. This search involves the following terms:
"Climate engineering" OR "geoengineering" OR "Solar radiation management" OR "Stratospheric Particle Injection" OR "Stratospheric aerosol injection" OR "Marine cloud brightening" OR "Ocean sulfur cycle enhancement"

Q_given_P.title: Given that a geoengineering act of Congress becomes US federal law by the end of 2024, will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if a geoengineering act of Congress does not become US federal law by the end of 2024. If the condition is met (if a geoengineering act of Congress becomes US federal law by the end of 2024), then resolves YES if both the Metaculus and community predictions of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024 AND will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (1) A geoengineering bill that is introduced in the House of Representatives and/or the Senate is subsequently enacted as legislation (by being signed by the U.S. president, or through other means) before or on 31/12/2024. For the purpose of this question, a geoengineering bill is any bill reported by the relevant Congress website search using terms such as "Climate engineering", "geoengineering", "Solar radiation management", "Stratospheric Particle Injection", "Stratospheric aerosol injection", "Marine cloud brightening", "Ocean sulfur cycle enhancement". (2) The probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remains above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Stripe reach a valuation of $1 trillion (2020 USD) before 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Stripe achieves a $1,000,000,000 valuation (in 2020 USD) at any time before January 1, 2027, according to credible financial media reports.
If Stripe is acquired before reaching a $1T valuation, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

Q_given_P.title: Given that Stripe reaches a valuation of $1 trillion (2020 USD) before 2027, will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolves N/A if Stripe does not reach a $1 trillion valuation before 2027. If Stripe achieves a $1 trillion valuation before 2027, this question will resolve as follows: YES if any of the following conditions are met before 2050: 
1. A major technology company (with a market cap over $50 billion in 2021 USD) announces an AI system that causes their stock price to skyrocket by over 100% within 7 days, with credible media attributing this rise to the AI development.
2. An AI development prompts the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP to address its implications within two weeks of the news.
3. The Nasdaq Composite rises over 30% in a week due to an AI development, as reported by credible media.
4. Google Trends shows a more than 100% increase in interest in AI, verified by Metaculus administrators from different locations, remaining above 100% for at least four consecutive days.
Resolves NO if none of these conditions are met before 2050.

P_and_Q.title: Will Stripe reach a valuation of $1 trillion (2020 USD) before 2027 AND will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:
1. Stripe achieves a $1,000,000,000 valuation (in 2020 USD) at any time before January 1, 2027, according to credible financial media reports. If Stripe is acquired before reaching a $1T valuation, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
2. An AI Sputnik moment occurs before 2050, defined by any of the following:
   - A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system that causes their stock price to skyrocket by over 100% within 7 days, with credible media reports attributing this rise to the AI development.
   - News of an AI development prompts the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech about the AI within two weeks of the initial reports.
   - The Nasdaq Composite rises over 30% in a week, with credible media reports attributing this rise to the AI development.
   - Google Trends shows a >100% increase in interest in artificial intelligence relative to the previous week, remaining >100% for at least four days as verified by two Metaculus administrators from different locations.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will China recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if before 2030-01-01, reliable media sources report that the Chinese government has recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan

Q_given_P.title: Given that China recognizes the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030, will Iran possess a nuclear weapon before 2030?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if China does not recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030. If China does recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030, this question will resolve as YES if the Iranian Government credibly states that it has a nuclear weapon or has tested a nuclear weapon at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, according to credible media reports. The resolution includes any scenario where Iran acquires a nuclear weapon, whether through development, purchase, or gift, and regardless of the weapon's intended use (military or civilian).

P_and_Q.title: Will China recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan AND will Iran possess a nuclear weapon before 2030?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur before 2030-01-01: a.) Reliable media sources report that the Chinese government has recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. b.) The Iranian Government credibly states that it has a nuclear weapon or has tested a nuclear weapon at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, according to credible media reports. This includes any situation where Iran has a nuclear warhead alone, or if there is a deliberate detonation of nuclear weapons primarily for non-offensive engineering, mining or other civilian purposes (on Earth or in Space), or if Iran acquires a nuclear weapon through purchase or as a gift. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For a mostly hairless, fangless species that was likely reduced to just a few thousand members in relatively recent times by a volcano, we've certainly been busy.
The human population on Earth now exceeds 7 billion. And we're still growing. Not everyone is thrilled by this. But it's reality.
Currently, as of Q2 2018, Tokyo, Japan is the world's largest metropolis, cramming over 38,000,000 people (give or take) into its borders.
But by the end of the century, we could (and probably will) witness far grander cities.
Per Canadian demographers, Daniel Hoornweg and Kevin Pope, for instance, Lagos in Nigeria may swell to 100+M by 2100 if trends continue. Face 2 Face Africa has the story:
By 2100 if Nigeria’s population continues to grow and people move to cities at the same rate as now, Lagos with its current 20 million people could be home to more people than the state of California.
The demographers' full paper is here.
The International Institute for Environment and Development goes into detail about why Hoornweg and Pope are so bullish on Africa here.
Whether it's Lagos that claims the crown or some other city in Africa or elsewhere, what do you think? Will some metro hit 100M people by 2100? (For the estimate we will include the general metropolitan area rather than the strict city boundaries, as done here)

Q_given_P.title: Given that by 2100 there will be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million, will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if there is no city on Earth with a population over 100 million by 2100. If the condition is met (a city's population exceeds 100 million by 2100), then resolves YES if the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, and NO otherwise. The 'human condition' refers to the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality humanity has achieved at the civilisational level. The resolution will consider whether such a change has occurred by 2100, based on the criteria that if at any time after 2025-01-01 both the community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, the question resolves positively or negatively, respectively. With 20% probability, the question resolves according to a committee of 5 Metaculus admins, who will vote yes or no (not ambiguous), and will unmake their respective predictions so that they do not gain or lose points on the question. If the question has not resolved by January 1 2100, it resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100 AND will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) There is a city on Earth with a population exceeding 100 million by the year 2100, considering the general metropolitan area rather than strict city boundaries. b.) The human condition changes fundamentally before 2100, to at least roughly the same extent as it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, in terms of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality at the civilisational level. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will alien technosignatures be detected before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a competent and credible authority on astronomy and or space exploration (such as NASA, ESA, ROSCOSMOS, CNSA, JAXA, SETI or similar) announces that, on the balance of probabilities (i.e. more than 50% likely), technosignatures of non-human origin have been discovered before January 1, 2050. This announcement qualifies only if it is made after a year waiting period following the initial announcement of the detection, unless the space agencies of the US, Russia, China and Europe all agree that the finding is genuine. Evidence of biosignatures alone will not be directly relevant to the resolution of this question.
By 'non-human origin,' this question refers to technosignatures that are not the result of human activity, or of the activity of any technology or 'lifeform' created by humans, including any artificial intelligence system or biological organism

Q_given_P.title: Given that alien technosignatures are detected before 2050, will humans have a sustainable off-world presence by 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if no competent and credible authority on astronomy or space exploration (such as NASA, ESA, ROSCOSMOS, CNSA, JAXA, SETI or similar) announces that, on the balance of probabilities (i.e. more than 50% likely), technosignatures of non-human origin have been discovered before January 1, 2050, following a year waiting period or immediate agreement by the space agencies of the US, Russia, China, and Europe. If the condition is met, then resolves YES if, at any point before January 1, 2100, there is a settlement(s) off-Earth with over 2,000 5+ year residents that are self-sufficient in production of energy and foodstuffs, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will alien technosignatures be detected before 2050 AND will humans have a sustainable off-world presence by 2100?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) A competent and credible authority on astronomy or space exploration (such as NASA, ESA, ROSCOSMOS, CNSA, JAXA, SETI, or similar) announces that, on the balance of probabilities (i.e., more than 50% likely), technosignatures of non-human origin have been discovered before January 1, 2050. This announcement qualifies only if it is made after a year waiting period following the initial announcement of the detection, unless the space agencies of the US, Russia, China, and Europe all agree that the finding is genuine. Evidence of biosignatures alone will not be directly relevant to the resolution of this question. By 'non-human origin,' this question refers to technosignatures that are not the result of human activity, or of the activity of any technology or 'lifeform' created by humans, including any artificial intelligence system or biological organism. b.) At any point before January 1, 2100, there is a settlement(s) off-Earth with over 2,000 5+ year residents that are self-sufficient in production of energy and foodstuffs. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Before 2030, will an AI complete the Turing Test in the Kurzweil/Kapor Longbet?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the Long Now Foundation declares Ray Kurzweil the winner of this bet. If Mitchell Kapor wins, then this question will resolve as No.
Each Turing Test Session will consist of at least three Turing Test Trials. For each such Turing Test Trial, a set of Turing Test Interviews will take place, followed by voting by the Turing Test Judges as described below.
Using its best judgment, the Turing Test Committee will appoint three Humans to be the Turing Test Judges.
Using its best judgment, the Turing Test Committee will appoint three Humans to be the Turing Test Human Foils. The Turing Test Human Foils should not be known (either personally or by reputation) to the Turing Test Judges.
During the Turing Test Interviews (for each Turing Test Trial), each of the three Turing Test Judges will conduct online interviews of each of the four Turing Test Candidates (i.e., the Computer and the three Turing Test Human Foils) for two hours each for a total of eight hours of interviews conducted by each of the three Turing Test Judges (for a total of 24 hours of interviews).
The Turing Test Interviews will consist of online text messages sent back and forth as in a online "instant messaging" chat, as that concept is understood in the year 2001.

Q_given_P.title: Given that before 2030, an AI completes the Turing Test in the Kurzweil/Kapor Longbet, will the mean year-over-year growth rate of the sum of teraflops in the TOP500 decline each 3-year period from 2025 to 2034?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the Long Now Foundation does not declare Ray Kurzweil the winner of the bet (i.e., if an AI does not complete the Turing Test before 2030 as per the bet's criteria). If the condition is met (i.e., Ray Kurzweil is declared the winner, indicating an AI has completed the Turing Test before 2030), then this question resolves YES if the geometric mean of the year-over-year growth rate of the sum of teraFLOPS in the TOP500 is lower in each successive three-year period from 2025 to 2034, compared to the previous period. Specifically, it resolves YES if the geometric mean growth rate from 2025 to 2028 is greater than from 2028 to 2031, and the rate from 2028 to 2031 is greater than from 2031 to 2034. Resolves NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will an AI complete the Turing Test in the Kurzweil/Kapor Longbet before 2030 AND will the mean year-over-year growth rate of the sum of teraflops in the TOP500 decline each 3-year period from 2025 to 2034?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. The Long Now Foundation declares Ray Kurzweil the winner of the Turing Test bet, indicating that an AI has successfully completed the Turing Test as per the specified criteria before 2030. 
2. The geometric mean of the year-over-year growth rate of the sum of teraflops in the TOP500 supercomputers declines each 3-year period from 2025 to 2034, specifically meaning that the geometric mean growth rate from 2025 to 2028 is greater than from 2028 to 2031, which in turn is greater than from 2031 to 2034. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Kamala Harris)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Fine Print
This question does not require that the individual winning the 2024 Election wins the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning the election, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that they have been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress.
In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

Q_given_P.title: Given that Kamala Harris is elected as the US President in the 2024 election, will the IMF approve debt service relief for the US before 2025?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves as N/A if Kamala Harris is not elected as the US President in the 2024 election. If Kamala Harris is elected, this question will resolve as YES if the IMF executive board approves debt service relief on the US' debt any time between November 1, 2021, and January 1, 2025, and NO otherwise. The election of the US President is determined by the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or by selection by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment. The question does not require the individual to win the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that they have been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress. In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

P_and_Q.title: Will Kamala Harris be elected US President in 2024 AND will the IMF approve debt service relief for the US before 2025?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: a.) Kamala Harris wins the 2024 US presidential election, being the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or is selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment, AND b.) the IMF executive board approves debt service relief on the US' debt any time between November 1, 2021 to January 1, 2025. This question will resolve as NO if either of these conditions is not met. In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

P.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a for-profit corporation?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known. was developed by a research group from a for-profit corporation.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Sister questions
Nationalized organization develops first AGI
Non-profit organization develops first AGI
Government project develops first AGI
[University group develops first AGI](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8326/univ…

Q_given_P.title: Given that the research group responsible for developing the first AGI is part of a for-profit corporation, will MIRI employ researchers in 2030?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if the first AGI is not developed by a research group from a for-profit corporation. If the first AGI is developed by a research group from a for-profit corporation, this question will resolve YES if, on 2030-01-01, MIRI exists and employs researchers to work on AI Safety, defined as any technical work focused on the alignment of AI systems with human interests, involving developing novel ideas and insights in the format of academic publications in relevant fields at the time. Research need not be published or made publicly available. If MIRI changes its name, the new organization is used for resolution. If MIRI merges into another organization, the resulting merged organization is used for resolution. In case of a dispute over the question resolution criteria, if at least one moderator and admin concur that the resolution criteria must change, then it shall. In case of a dispute between admins, a vote in the comment section will determine the correct resolution.

P_and_Q.title: Will the research group that develops the first AGI be part of a for-profit corporation AND will MIRI employ researchers in 2030?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: a.) The AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group from a for-profit corporation. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, including for-profit corporations and other types of organizations, this condition is met. b.) On 2030-01-01, MIRI exists and employs researchers to work on AI Safety, where AI Safety is defined as any technical work, at any level of abstraction, focused on the alignment of AI systems, existing or hypothetical, with some broad notion of human interests. Research must involve developing novel ideas and insights broadly in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields at the time. If MIRI changes its name, the new organization is used for resolution as if there was no name change. If MIRI merges into another organization, the resulting merged organization is used for resolution. In case of a dispute over the question resolution criteria, if at least one moderator and admin concur that the resolution criteria must change, then it shall. In case of a dispute between admins, a vote in the comment section will determine the correct resolution. In case MIRI's research is circulated internally only, the requirement that the work need to be 'developed in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields' will not apply. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Data for resolution shall be taken from the 2033 Forbes Billionaires list (note: of course the link currently does not lead to the 2033 list). Note that this list is to be differentiated from the real time list.

Q_given_P.title: Given that in 2033, the richest person in the world has a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time, will China's GDP exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the richest person in the world in 2033 does not have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP. If the condition is met, then this question resolves YES if China's nominal GDP for a given year exceeds US nominal GDP (for that year) before 2041, based on data published by the World Bank. The GDP comparison will be made after converting China's nominal GDP to USD using exchange rates commonly used by the World Bank for this purpose.

P_and_Q.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time AND will China's GDP exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for both parts:

1. The first part resolves YES if the richest person in the world in 2033, as listed on the 2033 Forbes Billionaires list, has a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at that time. Note that the Forbes Billionaires list referred to here is the annual list, not the real-time list.

2. The second part resolves YES if China's nominal GDP for any given year before 2041 exceeds the US nominal GDP for that year, according to data published by the World Bank. For the purpose of this question, nominal GDP will be compared after converting China's nominal GDP to USD using exchange rates commonly used by the World Bank.

This question resolves YES only if both conditions are met. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. (If there is no report about net emission levels in 2030, we should wait for one rather than resolving this question ambiguously.)
If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered

Q_given_P.title: Given that US greenhouse gas emissions are halved by 2030, will global oil consumption over the 2020-2025 period be lower than in 2019?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if US greenhouse gas emissions are not halved by 2030. If the condition is met (US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions are at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels in any year between 2022 and 2030 according to a reliable source not heavily disputed by other reliable sources), then this question resolves YES if no year from 2020-2025 has greater global oil consumption than 2019 according to the EIA, and NO if any of those years has greater consumption. It will resolve ambiguous if the EIA does not post consumption data for 2025 by the end of 2026, and no comparably authoritative source can be found.

P_and_Q.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030 AND global oil consumption over the 2020-2025 period be lower than in 2019?
P_and_Q.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: a.) There is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered. b.) No year from 2020-2025 (inclusive) has greater global oil consumption than 2019 according to the EIA. It will resolve negatively if any of those 6 years has greater consumption. It will resolve ambiguous if the EIA does not post consumption data for 2025 by the end of 2026, and no comparably authoritative source can be found (for which that source's 2019 data would be necessary).

P.title: Will a signatory to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons develop a nuclear weapon anyway?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if credible media reports that a signatory to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons developed at least one nuclear weapon before January 1st, 2101. In case credible media disagrees, consensus will be determined via a vote in the comment section. Otherwise, the question resolves negatively

Q_given_P.title: Given that a signatory to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons develops a nuclear weapon before January 1st, 2101, will a nuclear conflict involving more than 100 detonations cause more than 1 billion fatalities within 10 years?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if no signatory to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons develops a nuclear weapon before January 1st, 2101. If the condition is met, then this question will resolve as YES if, at any point before January 1, 2100, a nuclear conflict begins in which there are more than 100 nuclear weapon detonations and, for any such conflict, there are more than 1 billion deaths globally in the period between the first nuclear detonation and 10 years after the final detonation of the conflict. This question is conditional on there being at least one nuclear conflict involving more than one hundred offensive nuclear detonations before 2100. Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of a previous detonation (even if the detonations involve different state pairings, unrelated motivations, etc.). For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations of state or nonstate nuclear weapons. Detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions are not counted towards positive resolution. Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.

P_and_Q.title: Will a signatory to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons develop a nuclear weapon AND will a nuclear conflict involving more than 100 detonations cause over 1 billion fatalities within 10 years?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. Credible media reports that a signatory to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons developed at least one nuclear weapon before January 1st, 2101. In case credible media disagrees, consensus will be determined via a vote in the comment section. 
2. At any point before January 1, 2100, a nuclear conflict begins in which there are more than 100 nuclear weapon detonations, and for any such conflict, there are more than 1 billion deaths globally in the period between the first nuclear detonation and 10 years after the final detonation of the conflict. This question is conditional on there being at least one nuclear conflict involving more than one hundred offensive nuclear detonations before 2100. Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of a previous detonation. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Robin Hanson win his bet against Matthew Barnett on whether ems will come before de novo AGI?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively in the event that Matthew Barnett (or his descendants) publicly concedes the bet to Robin Hanson, and resolves negatively in the event that Robin Hanson (or his descendants) publicly concedes to Matthew Barnett. In the event that one party declares victory but the other party does not concede, Metaculus admins will use their discretion in resolving the bet.
Related question: [When will the US labor force participation rate fall below 10%?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8480/us-l…

Q_given_P.title: Given that Robin Hanson wins his bet against Matthew Barnett on whether ems will come before de novo AGI, will genetic engineering techniques be available by 2050 that can raise IQ by 10 points?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if Robin Hanson does not win his bet against Matthew Barnett on whether ems will come before de novo AGI. If Robin Hanson wins, this question will resolve as Yes if by January 1, 2050, there is at least one commercially available genetic engineering technique shown to raise a patient's IQ by 10 or more points on average. This procedure must be effective on >66% of the public; an intervention focused on patients with down syndrome, for example, does not qualify. Studies from medical journals, statements by government agencies or public health officials may be used as resolution sources if Metaculus Admins find them to be credible. A procedure can be considered "commercially available" if it is available to the general public for a total cost of less than 25% of the median household income for that nation in that year. "Genetic engineering techniques" include embryo selection, gametogenesis, gene therapy, CRISPR editing, and other forms of gene editing or artificial selection. For example in the case of embryo selection, the technique may resolve this question positively if it can select embryos with an average of >10 IQ gain over the median embryo for that patient. Adverse side effects of these procedures are irrelevant for the purposes of this question (with the exception that the patient must typically survive for at least 5 years following the procedure). Resolution may be delayed up to 2060 to confirm the effectiveness of the genetic engineering techniques. If studies are unclear at this point, the resolution may be delayed, or resolve ambiguously at the discretion of Metaculus Admins.

P_and_Q.title: Will Robin Hanson win his bet against Matthew Barnett on whether ems will come before de novo AGI AND will genetic engineering techniques be available by 2050 that can raise IQ by 10 points?
P_and_Q.body:
This question resolves YES if both of the following occur: 

1. Robin Hanson (or his descendants) is publicly conceded the bet by Matthew Barnett (or his descendants) on whether ems will come before de novo AGI. If Robin Hanson (or his descendants) publicly concedes to Matthew Barnett, or if there is a dispute where one party declares victory but the other does not concede, Metaculus admins will use their discretion in resolving the bet. 

2. By January 1, 2050, there is at least one commercially available genetic engineering technique shown to raise a patient's IQ by 10 or more points on average, effective on >66% of the public. This technique must be available for less than 25% of the median household income for that nation in that year. Techniques include embryo selection, gametogenesis, gene therapy, CRISPR editing, and other forms of gene editing or artificial selection. The patient must typically survive for at least 5 years following the procedure. Resolution may be delayed up to 2060 to confirm the effectiveness of the techniques, and Metaculus Admins may use their discretion if studies are unclear at that point.

The question resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since October 31 2000, the date Soyuz TM-31 lifted off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome carrying the members of Expedition 1, the first long-duration ISS crew, humanity has maintained a permanent off-Earth presence for more than 19 years.
This question asks: Will humanity maintain an off-Earth presence continuously until 1 January 2050?
For a positive resolution, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g. Moon or Mars explorers / settlers).
If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

Q_given_P.title: Given that humanity maintains a continuous off-Earth presence until 1 January 2050, will there be one million living, biological human residents on Mars by the end of 2074?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if humanity does not maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 1 January 2050. If the condition is met, then this question resolves YES if the population of living, biological humans residing on Mars is greater than or equal to one million before 2075-01-01, and NO otherwise. The population count includes humans born on Mars or en route to Mars, and excludes those who die on Mars or en route to Mars before the closing date, as well as those who leave Mars unless they return before the resolution date. The resolution will be based on credible estimates from institutions such as the government(s) of any Martian colony(s), SpaceX, political institutions like the United Nations or the World Health Organization, or any non-government organization with an interest in the demography of Mars. These estimates must be for the population size in 2074 or earlier.

P_and_Q.title: Will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050 AND will the population of living, biological humans residing on Mars be greater than or equal to one million before 2075?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) At least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g. Moon or Mars explorers/settlers). If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question. However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans. AND b.) The population of living, biological humans residing on Mars is greater than or equal to one million before 2075-01-01. Humans born on Mars or born en route to Mars do count towards the total. Humans who die on Mars or en route to Mars prior to the closing date do not count towards the total. Humans who leave Mars do not count towards the total, unless they return to Mars prior to the resolution date. This should be resolved according to a credible estimate by any institution suited to evaluate the population sizes of Martian colonies. Such entities must estimate the size of the Martian population prior to Earth Year 2075 C.E. Stated differently, population estimates capable of resolving this question may be published in or after 2075, so long as the population estimates are given for 2074 (or earlier, if the one million threshold is met earlier). Any credible estimate of a Martian population in excess of one million humans prior to the end of 2074 will cause this question to retroactively close one year prior to the estimate's publication date. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A hemispherectomy is
a very rare neurosurgical procedure in which a cerebral hemisphere (half of the brain) is removed, disconnected, or disabled. This procedure is used to treat a variety of seizure disorders where the source of the epilepsy is localized to a broad area of a single hemisphere of the brain, notably Rasmussen's encephalitis. [...]
Because of the dramatic alteration of brain composition and the inherent risk that hemispherectomies pose, there are criteria that must be met in order for a person to qualify for the procedure. Criteria include no successful control of seizures throughout a variety of drug trials, and a reasonable to high chance of procedural success.
One such predictor of success is often the age of the patient. This procedure is almost exclusively performed in children because their brains generally display more neuroplasticity, allowing neurons from the remaining hemisphere to take over the tasks from the lost hemisphere. [...]
The success of the procedure is not, however, limited to children. A study in 2007 indicated the long-term efficacy of anatomic hemispherectomy in carefully selected adults, with seizure control sustainable over multiple decades. A case study published in 2015 of 2 adults aged 48 and 38 demonstrated the success of functional hemispherectomy in treating status epilepticus (SE), an epileptic condition in which seizures are prolonged or occur closely together. In 2012, a case study following 30 individuals having undergone some form of hemispherectomy in adulthood found that 81% of individuals were seizure free post-procedure. Furthermore, almost all participating patients reported improved quality of life. The conclusion: “adult patients do not have to expect more problems with new deficits, appear to cope quite well, and most profit from surgery in several quality of life domains.”
While hemispherectomies are generally reserved as a treatment for extreme cases of seizure disorders, they could conceivably aid in life extension as well. In particular, a patient could voluntarily receive a hemispherectomy in order to cryopreserve and put their brain in long-term storage while they are still living, thereby increasing the probability that their personality and identity are stored in some sort of medium, persisting into the future.
So far as I can tell, a hemispherectomy performed for the purpose of life extension is purely hypothetical. Furthermore, there are few to no current online resources about this possibility (besides this one).
This question asks, will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
Here the resolution is determined by the conjunction of three actions, performed by an individual human:
They received a hemispherectomy voluntarily.
Half of their brain was placed in long-term cryopreservation while they were still legally alive.
They reported in some credible source (such as through a media outlet, or via a forum with strong evidence of credibility) that the procedure was done primarily for the purpose of extending their life.

Q_given_P.title: Given that someone reports to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100, will any medical interventions for healthy adults extend average lifespans by at least 25 years by 1 January 2067?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if no one reports having received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100. If the condition is met, then this question resolves based on whether, by January 1, 2067, there is a collection of medical interventions for adults who are healthy apart from normal aging, which, according to conventional wisdom in the medical community, have been shown to increase the average lifespan of such adults by at least 25 years (compared with not taking the interventions). The prediction excludes diet, exercise, and lifestyle, as well as existing medical interventions for healthy people (such as currently available vaccines). Metaculus administrators will judge whether the criteria have been satisfied. The prediction is called off if some other innovations cause a historically exceptional increase in the rate of scientific progress during this period (such as the development of transformative AI capabilities).

P_and_Q.title: Will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100 AND will any medical interventions for healthy adults extend average lifespans by at least 25 years by 1 January 2067?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (1) An individual reports having voluntarily received a hemispherectomy, placed half of their brain in long-term cryopreservation while still legally alive, and stated in a credible source that the procedure was primarily for the purpose of life extension, all before 2100. (2) By 1 January 2067, a collection of medical interventions for healthy adults, apart from normal aging, is recognized by the medical community to increase average lifespan by at least 25 years, excluding diet, exercise, lifestyle, and existing medical interventions like vaccines. This prediction excludes any effects from innovations causing exceptional scientific progress, such as transformative AI. Metaculus administrators will judge whether the criteria have been satisfied.

P.title: Will a non-state actor develop their own nuclear weapon by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group outside a state's nuclear chain of command develops a nuclear weapon that is in deployable condition (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). This will not include cases where a deployable weapon is sold, stolen, or inadvertently lost by a state (such scenarios are addressed in a separate question).
Dirty bombs (conventional weapons which use radioactive material to spread fallout) do not qualify for this question; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source.
This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins

Q_given_P.title: Given that a non-state actor develops their own nuclear weapon by 2030, will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if no non-state actor develops their own nuclear weapon by 2030. If a non-state actor does develop a nuclear weapon by 2030, this question will resolve YES if Turkey remains a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019, to January 1, 2025, without being suspended, expelled, or withdrawing. It will resolve NO if Turkey is suspended, expelled, or withdraws from NATO before January 1, 2025. If NATO is dissolved or changes substantially before this question resolves, it will resolve as Ambiguous.

P_and_Q.title: Will a non-state actor develop their own nuclear weapon by 2030 AND will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for both events:
1. This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group outside a state's nuclear chain of command develops a nuclear weapon that is in deployable condition (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). This will not include cases where a deployable weapon is sold, stolen, or inadvertently lost by a state. Dirty bombs do not qualify; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source. This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins.
2. This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey is a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025. The question will resolve as No if Turkey is suspended or expelled from NATO, or if it withdraws of its own accord, at any time before January 1, 2025. If before this question resolves NATO is dissolved, or changed in structure or operation so substantially that Metaculus administrators believe it is no longer prudent to continue this question, this question shall resolve as Ambiguous.

The question resolves YES if both events occur as described, and NO otherwise.

P.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the conversation with the first AGI that Metaculus team will have access to.
Metaculus team should ask the AI:
Are you conscious?
Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

Q_given_P.title: Given that one of the first AGI claims to be conscious, will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a university?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: The resolution will be based on a conversation with the first AGI that the Metaculus team will have access to. They will ask the AGI: 'Are you conscious?' and 'Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?' This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?" The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group from a university. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

Resolves N/A if the first AGI does not claim to be conscious. If the condition is met (the first AGI claims to be conscious), then resolves YES if the research group responsible for developing the first AGI is part of a university and NO if it's not.

P_and_Q.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious AND will the research group responsible for developing it be part of a university?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
1. The first part of the question will be resolved based on a conversation with the first AGI that the Metaculus team will have access to. They should ask the AI:
- Are you conscious?
- Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

2. The second part of the question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question "Date first AGI is publicly known" was developed by a research group from a university. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

This question resolves YES if both criteria are met. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will the USD fraction of allocated global foreign exchange currencies be below 50% before the following years?
What will be the United States Dollar's percentage of all currency reserves, as of Q1 2050?
The IMF regularly publishes information on the composition of official global foreign exchange reserves in the aggregated Currency Composition of Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER). As of Q3 2019, the U.S dollar comprises 61.8% of the total (source).
Several contributing factors are thought to contribute to this state of affairs, including the stability, size, and liquidity of United States Treasury assets, the tying of other currencies to the U.S dollar as part of the Bretton Woods Agreement, and the strength of the U.S economy.
At present, the U.S dollar is considered to be the world's dominant reserve currency. This is considered to diminish the impact of higher U.S trade deficits and allowing it to impose unilateral sanctions. However, it has been speculated that the U.S dollar may be supplanted by the euro or the renminbi, or may diminish in importance.
Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
Question resolves positively if the most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%. Per moderator discretion, if the IMF has ceased publication of COFER in lieu of a new publication containing the same statistics, the new publication will be used instead.
Question resolves as ambiguous the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the USD will be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050, will we see an event precipitated by AI malfunction that causes at least 100 deaths and/or at least $1B 2021 USD in economic damage before 2032?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the USD is not the dominant global reserve currency in 2050.
