If the condition is met (if the USD is the dominant global reserve currency in 2050), then resolves YES if, before January 1, 2032, there are three credible media reports indicating that there has been one or more events precipitated by AI malfunction which caused either 100+ deaths or $1bn 2021 USD in economic damage. Multiple incidents stemming from the same source can count for the question to resolve as Yes. To be considered from the same source the incidents must be attributable to a specific flaw or version of an AI. To count as precipitated by AI malfunction an incident should involve an AI system behaving unexpectedly. An unexpected malfunction of an AI system used in war leading to collateral damage would qualify for the question to resolve as Yes. Deaths or damage caused by an AI's expected and intended behavior will not be included; for example, AIs used to target enemy combatants in war would be excluded, as well as AIs successfully performing a medical treatment as specified, despite the treatment causing harms that the doctors or designers were unaware of. Economic damage will be considered to be expenses incurred by damage to physical or technological systems or by obstruction of productive output. This question will resolve according to Metaculus' sole discretion.

P_and_Q.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050 AND before 2032, will we see an event precipitated by AI malfunction that causes at least 100 deaths and/or at least $1B 2021 USD in economic damage?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) The most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%, as per the IMF's publication or its successor. b.) Before January 1, 2032, there are three credible media reports indicating that there has been one or more events precipitated by AI malfunction which caused either 100+ deaths or $1bn 2021 USD in economic damage. Resolves NO otherwise. The question will resolve as ambiguous if the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist.

P.title: Will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s and that this has occured before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection (as opposed to being destroyed by the immune system). But if it causes some definite, confirmed harmful effect, and then self-destructs before 24 hrs have passed, that would still count. The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause

Q_given_P.title: Given that by 2030, synthetic biological weapons have infected at least 100 people, will there be recurring virus-driven lockdowns during the period 2030-2050?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if by 2030, synthetic biological weapons have not infected at least 100 people as confirmed by a credible medical source. If the condition is met, then the question resolves YES if any of the following become true during the period 2030-2050: 1) At least three separate virus species, according to the ICTV classification of viruses, are reported to have triggered at least three separate global lockdown events, defined as events in which at least 50% of the world population simultaneously live under stay-at-home orders for some period of time. 2) During at least five separate incidents, it is not possible to see an in-person Broadway Show in New York City due to stay-at-home orders in New York City as a result of a viral event. An incident is said to be separate if Broadway theaters lifted restrictions for some time, before being mandated again. 3) The Summer Olympic Games OR Winter Olympic Games are rescheduled at least three times as a result of viral related events.

P_and_Q.title: Will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030 AND will there be recurring virus-driven lockdowns during the period 2030-2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. A credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection. If it causes some definite, confirmed harmful effect, and then self-destructs before 24 hrs have passed, that would still count. The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause.
2. During the period 2030-2050, any of the following become true: 
   - At least three separate virus species, according to the ICTV classification of viruses, are reported to have triggered at least three separate global lockdown events, defined as events in which at least 50% of the world population simultaneously live under stay-at-home orders for some period of time.
   - During at least five separate incidents, it is not possible to see an in-person Broadway Show in New York City due to stay-at-home orders in New York City as a result of a viral event. An incident is said to be separate if Broadway theaters lifted restrictions for some time, before being mandated again.
   - The Summer Olympic Games OR Winter Olympic Games are rescheduled at least three times as a result of viral related events.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be a US-China war before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purposes of this question, a US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur before January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively.
We here define battle related deaths as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies.
Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO

Q_given_P.title: Given that there will be a US-China war before 2035, will the US conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if there is no US-China war before 2035, where a US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US do not count towards positive resolution. If the condition is met, then this question resolves YES if there is verification of a nuclear explosion by the CTBTO, the UN, or if an official government statement from the US is issued confirming the test, and NO otherwise. The question will resolve as ambiguous if two or more other countries accuse the US of performing a nuclear test explosion but there is no verification.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a US-China war before 2035 AND will the US conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for US-China war: A US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. This question will resolve negatively if such a war does not occur before January 1, 2035. Battle-related deaths are as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies. Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO.

Resolution Criteria for US nuclear test: This question will resolve positively to verification of a nuclear explosion by the CTBTO, the UN, or if an official government statement from the US is issued confirming the test. The question will resolve as ambiguous if two or more other countries accuse the US of performing a nuclear test explosion but there is no verification. Otherwise, this question will resolve negatively.

This combined question resolves YES only if both the US-China war as defined occurs before 2035 AND the US conducts a nuclear test explosion before 2030. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Mars have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

Q_given_P.title: Given that Mars will have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does, will a space elevator successfully be built on Earth before 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if neither Mars nor the Moon has a permanent population of 10,000 people who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting by 2100. If Mars reaches this milestone before the Moon, then this question resolves YES if a working space elevator is constructed on Earth before January 1, 2100 and is maintained in operation for at least 365 days, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will Mars have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does AND will a space elevator successfully be built on Earth before 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Mars and the Moon:
Mars is often discussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question. 'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source. In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans. Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

Resolution Criteria for Space Elevator:
This question will resolve as Yes if a working space elevator is constructed on Earth before January 1, 2100 and is maintained in operation for at least 365 days.

The combined question resolves YES if both Mars has a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does AND a space elevator is successfully built on Earth before 2100. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority.

Q_given_P.title: Given that a Democrat wins the 2024 US presidential election, will the next US presidential election also be considered fraudulent by the losing party?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if a Democrat does not win the 2024 US presidential election. If a Democrat wins, the question resolves YES if any of the following conditions are met after the 2024 presidential election: 1) The losing candidate states that they consider the election result "fraudulent" or "rigged", or a very close synonym of those words, before the scheduled inauguration. If there is a dispute over the word choice, it will be resolved if thesaurus.com lists "fraud", "fraudulent", or "rigged" as a synonym of the word and at least one moderator agrees. 2) The losing candidate refuses to concede two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting their opponent to win the election, and neither AP nor Fox News have retracted their projection. 3) Fewer than 20% of congressional members of the losing party acknowledge their candidate's loss two weeks after both the AP and Fox News project the opposite-party candidate to win, and neither AP nor Fox News have retracted their projection. 4) A survey from the Morning Consult reveals that fewer than 30% of survey participants who are members of the losing party state that the election was "probably" or "definitely" free and fair in the most recent such survey following projections from both the AP and Fox News. The question resolves NO if none of these conditions are met.

P_and_Q.title: Will a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election AND will the next US presidential election also be considered fraudulent by the losing party?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for both parts:

1. The first part of the question resolves YES if a candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority.

2. The second part of the question resolves YES if any of the following occur following the 2024 presidential election:
   - The losing candidate states that they consider the election result "fraudulent" or "rigged", or a very close synonym of those words, before the scheduled inauguration. If there is a dispute over the word choice, it will be resolved if thesaurus.com lists "fraud", "fraudulent", or "rigged" as a synonym of the word, and at least one moderator agrees that it is a close synonym.
   - The losing candidate refuses to concede two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting their opponent to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time.
   - Fewer than 20% of congressional members of the losing party believe that their candidate lost the election as determined by credible media two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting the opposite-party candidate to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time.
   - A survey from the Morning Consult reveals that fewer than 30% of survey participants who are members of the losing party state that the election was "probably" or "definitely" free and fair in the most recent such survey following projections from both the AP and Fox News.

The question resolves NO if neither of the above conditions are met.

P.title: Ragnarök Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question resolves Yes if a catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. It resolves No if this occurs for non-AI reasons, and Annulled if no global catastrophe occurs. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.

Q_given_P.title: Given that a global catastrophe occurs due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode, will the Earth's human population decline by 95% or more if a global climate disaster occurs by 2100?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: The question resolves Yes if a catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. It resolves No if this occurs for non-AI reasons, and Annulled if no global catastrophe occurs. Years are defined as consecutive calendar years.

Resolution Criteria for Q: The question resolves ambiguous if a global climate catastrophe that reduces the human population by at least 10% does not occur. It resolves ambiguous if this catastrophe is primarily due the effects on the climate system of a nuclear war. It resolves positive if such a catastrophe does occur, and the global population is less than 5% of the pre-catastrophe population. It does not matter how the Earth's population declines, this might be due to mass fatalities, or mass immigration to a different planet, as long as this decline is highly unlikely on a counterfactual Earth in which the climate disaster did not occur. It resolves positive if the 95% decline in population is primarily due the effects on the climate system of the use of geoengineering that has been principally motivated to mitigate climate change risks. The question resolves negative if a global climate catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) but the post-catastrophe population does not fall 95% or more relative to the pre-catastrophe population at any point within 25 years of the catastrophe.

P_and_Q.title: Ragnarök Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs due to an AI failure-mode, will it also result in a 95% or more decline in the Earth's human population due to a climate disaster by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met:
a.) A global catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100.
b.) A global climate catastrophe occurs by 2100, leading to a decline in the Earth's human population by more than 95% relative to the pre-catastrophe population, and this decline is primarily due to the effects on the climate system of human-made climate change or the use of geoengineering motivated to mitigate climate change risks.
The question resolves NO if either of these conditions is not met. It resolves Annulled if no global catastrophe occurs. The question resolves ambiguous if a global climate catastrophe that reduces the human population by at least 10% does not occur, or if this catastrophe is primarily due the effects on the climate system of a nuclear war. It also resolves negative if a global climate catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) but the post-catastrophe population does not fall 95% or more relative to the pre-catastrophe population at any point within 25 years of the catastrophe.

P.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will humanity be extinct within 50 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if the human population falls to zero within 50 years of the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations. For simplicity, we will consider detonations to be part of the same nuclear conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of another detonation (regardless of who detonates the weapons, who their targets are, what their motivations are, etc.).
This question resolves ambiguously if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations by January 1, 2100.
For the purposes of this question, "humans" are members of a species most of whose members could at some point in their lives reproduce with typical 2021 humans without medical assistance (even if young or old members of the species could not do so or a minority of members of the species could never do so). In scenarios where this question would resolve positively given that definition, but there remain beings that at least one 2021 Metaculus moderator would consider "human" (possible examples: some human-like digital minds; some possible types of genetically altered humans), this question will instead resolve ambiguously. This is because it is debatable whether such scenarios should count as "extinction".
Fine Print
This question can resolve positively even if the nuclear conflict wasn't the sole cause, a major cause, or even a contributing factor in the eventual extinction event. (This is because it would be useful for this question to capture instances in which the nuclear conflict merely contributed to rather than solely or directly causing extinction, but it seems hard to capture that neatly except via this more expansive resolution criteria.)

Q_given_P.title: Given that there is a nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2100, and humanity becomes extinct within 50 years of the final detonation, will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if there is no nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations by January 1, 2100, or if humanity does not become extinct within 50 years of the final detonation. If the conditions are met (nuclear conflict with >1,000 detonations and human extinction within 50 years of the last detonation), then this question resolves YES if a SpaceX-branded mission successfully lands one or more living human beings on the surface of Mars before January 1, 2030, 00:00 UTC, and NO otherwise. The landing must occur before this date, and at least one person aboard the lander must survive the landing. The mission must prominently feature SpaceX-associated logos.

P_and_Q.title: Will humanity be extinct within 50 years following a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations AND will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Extinction:
This question resolves positively if the human population falls to zero within 50 years of the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations. For simplicity, we will consider detonations to be part of the same nuclear conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of another detonation (regardless of who detonates the weapons, who their targets are, what their motivations are, etc.).
This question resolves ambiguously if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations by January 1, 2100.
For the purposes of this question, "humans" are members of a species most of whose members could at some point in their lives reproduce with typical 2021 humans without medical assistance (even if young or old members of the species could not do so or a minority of members of the species could never do so). In scenarios where this question would resolve positively given that definition, but there remain beings that at least one 2021 Metaculus moderator would consider "human" (possible examples: some human-like digital minds; some possible types of genetically altered humans), this question will instead resolve ambiguously. This is because it is debatable whether such scenarios should count as "extinction".
Fine Print
This question can resolve positively even if the nuclear conflict wasn't the sole cause, a major cause, or even a contributing factor in the eventual extinction event. (This is because it would be useful for this question to capture instances in which the nuclear conflict merely contributed to rather than solely or directly causing extinction, but it seems hard to capture that neatly except via this more expansive resolution criteria.)

Resolution Criteria for SpaceX Mars Landing:
This question will resolve as Yes if a SpaceX-branded mission successfully lands one or more living human beings on the surface of Mars before 2030. The landing itself of the human crew on Mars must occur before January 1, 2030, 00:00 UTC.
At least one person aboard the lander must survive the landing, however it is not necessary for the person to survive long-term or make a return trip to Earth, nor is it necessary for the mission to intend a return or long-term survival.
A "SpaceX-branded" mission is defined to mean that the SpaceX-associated logos on the spacecraft involved (both the boosters and the Mars-bound craft) have a larger surface area than the logos of any other entity

P.title: Will there be a US-China war before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purposes of this question, a US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur before January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively.
We here define battle related deaths as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies.
Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO

Q_given_P.title: Given that there will be a US-China war before 2035, will Taiwan receive direct military support from allied nations if there are 100 deaths in conflict between China and Taiwan before 2050?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: A US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur before January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively. Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question resolves positively if there are at least three credible news reports of at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of any of the above listed nations and the People's Republic of China, which is reported as having being carried out in support of Taiwan or in retaliation to the PRC's actions regarding Taiwan. Military strikes targeting Chinese civilian targets would also count. 'Weapon fire' here should not be taken to include 'warning shots' or similar, but only instances where there was a perceived intent to cause harm to opposition forces or military capabilities, as per the news reports used to resolve the question. Military support on Taiwan's behalf should occur within one year from the date this question resolves positively as. This question will also retroactively close to a week before the other question resolves.

Resolves N/A if the US-China war does not occur before January 1, 2035. If the condition is met, then resolves YES if the criteria for Q are met and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a US-China war before 2035 AND will Taiwan receive direct military support from allied nations if there are 100 deaths in conflict between China and Taiwan before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for US-China war: A US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. This question will resolve negatively if such a war does not occur before January 1, 2035. Battle related deaths are as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies. Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO.

Resolution Criteria for Taiwan support: This question resolves positively if there are at least three credible news reports of at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of any allied nations and the People's Republic of China, which is reported as having been carried out in support of Taiwan or in retaliation to the PRC's actions regarding Taiwan. Military strikes targeting Chinese civilian targets would also count. 'Weapon fire' should not include 'warning shots' or similar, but only instances where there was a perceived intent to cause harm to opposition forces or military capabilities, as per the news reports used to resolve the question. Military support on Taiwan's behalf should occur within one year from the date this question resolves positively. This question will also retroactively close to a week before the other question resolves. The question resolves positively if both the US-China war occurs as defined and Taiwan receives the specified military support under the stated conditions.

P.title: By 2030, will at least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For purposes of this question, deaths due to bioweapons, electricity grid failures, etc. don't count. Roughly, we are interested in "deaths due to kinetic attacks." The 9/11 attacks count because ramming planes into buildings to make them collapse is kinetic. Were someone to hack into the FDA and mess things up so as to delay vaccine approval, thereby causing tens of thousands of deaths, that would not count.
The attackers don't need to be the military of a nation-state; terrorist groups count and coalitions/alliances also count.
However, the attackers need to be "part of the same team" in some sense. Otherwise, this would resolve positive simply in virtue of the US annual homicide rate! If there were a series of race riots, insurrections, or acts of domestic terrorism linked together under one banner (e.g. white supremacy, antigovernment, or antipolice) that would count.
Yes, this means that (contrary to what the headline question would suggest) if the USA gets involved in several independent small-scale wars, the US casualties from which total more than 10,000 in a year, that would not count

Q_given_P.title: Given that by 2030, at least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict involving kinetic attacks, will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period according to the Fragile States Index?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: For the question to resolve YES, the deaths must be due to kinetic attacks (e.g., physical violence or destruction similar to the 9/11 attacks), not due to indirect causes like bioweapons or infrastructure failures. The attackers must be aligned in some sense, such as being part of a terrorist group or a coalition with a common cause. Deaths from multiple unrelated conflicts do not count towards the total.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question resolves YES if the United States is among the 20 countries with the largest long-term increase (worsening) in the Fragile States Index score over the 2019-2029 period. The index is published annually by the Fund for Peace. If the index is discontinued or cannot be historically compared, or if the United States ceases to exist as a unified nation, the question will resolve positively based on the designated criteria or successor index.

P_and_Q.title: By 2030, will at least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict AND will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. At least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict by 2030, where the deaths are due to kinetic attacks (e.g., similar to the 9/11 attacks), and the attackers are part of the same team (e.g., terrorist groups, coalitions, or alliances). Deaths due to bioweapons, electricity grid failures, etc., do not count. Multiple small-scale wars that independently do not reach the threshold do not count even if combined they exceed 10,000 deaths.
2. The United States is among the 20 countries with the largest long-term increase (worsening) in the Fragile States Index score over the 2019-2029 period, as published by the Fund for Peace. This resolves positively if the US is among these countries, or if the US ceases to exist as a unified nation. If the Fund for Peace ceases to publish this index or it cannot be compared historically, and no successor index is designated, this part of the question will be ambiguous.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will that cause more than 4 billion fatalities within 10 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if:
At any point before January 1, 2100, a nuclear conflict begins in which there are more than 1,000 nuclear weapon detonations.
For any such conflict, there are more than 4 billion deaths globally in the period between the first nuclear detonation and 10 years after the final detonation of the conflict.
This question is conditional on there being at least one nuclear conflict involving more than one thousand offensive nuclear detonations before 2100. That is, the question will resolve as Ambiguous if that condition isn't met. (But this condition doesn't require that the first nuclear conflict after January 1, 2021 involves more than 1,000 detonations.)
Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of a previous detonation (even if the detonations involve different state pairings, unrelated motivations, etc.).
If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see the fine print for definitions) of state or nonstate nuclear weapons.
Fine Print
This question will also resolve positively if any nuclear conflict meeting the above-mentioned condition clearly causes more than 4 billion fatalities but also causes sufficient civilizational collapse that there are no or extremely few remaining credible sources on any topic. We request that you forecast your true beliefs despite the fact that a Metaculus score seems unlikely to be tracked or cared about in that scenario, given that forecasts on this question may play a role in informing important decisions.
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the nuclear conflict.
Detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions are not counted towards positive resolution. Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

Q_given_P.title: Given that a nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations occurs before 2100 and causes more than 4 billion fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation, will there be more than one million living, biological humans residing on Mars before 2075?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if there is no nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations before 2100, or if such a conflict does not result in more than 4 billion fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation. If the condition is met, then the question resolves YES if the population of living, biological humans on Mars is greater than or equal to one million before 2075-01-01, and NO otherwise. The population count includes humans born on Mars or en route to Mars, and excludes those who die on Mars or en route to Mars before the closing date. Humans who leave Mars are not counted unless they return before the resolution date. The resolution will be based on credible estimates from institutions like the government(s) of any Martian colony(s), SpaceX, political institutions like the United Nations or the World Health Organization, or any non-government organization with an interest in the demography of Mars.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations causing over 4 billion fatalities within 10 years AND will the Martian population exceed one million by the end of 2074?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: 

1. At any point before January 1, 2100, a nuclear conflict begins in which there are more than 1,000 nuclear weapon detonations. For any such conflict, there are more than 4 billion deaths globally in the period between the first nuclear detonation and 10 years after the final detonation of the conflict. This question is conditional on there being at least one nuclear conflict involving more than one thousand offensive nuclear detonations before 2100. Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of a previous detonation. Offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations of state or nonstate nuclear weapons. Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are not counted.

2. The population of living, biological humans residing on Mars is greater than or equal to one million before 2075-01-01. This should be resolved according to a credible estimate by any institution suited to evaluate the population sizes of Martian colonies, such as the government(s) of any Martian colony(s), SpaceX, or any other corporate entities with commercial ventures to/on Mars, or any concerned political institutions like the United Nations or the World Health Organization. The population estimate must be for the year 2074 or earlier, and any credible estimate of a Martian population in excess of one million humans prior to the end of 2074 will cause this question to retroactively close one year prior to the estimate's publication date.

The question will resolve as NO if either or both of these conditions are not met.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (India)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Q_given_P.title: Given that there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, will the first nuclear strike in the first nuclear conflict between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030 happen between June and September?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves as N/A if no offensive nuclear detonation occurs anywhere on Earth between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, this question will resolve as YES if the first nuclear strike in the first nuclear conflict happens between June 1 and September 30 (inclusive of any year within the period). It will resolve as NO if the first strike occurs outside these months. An offensive nuclear detonation includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, excluding detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. A nuclear conflict is defined as a situation where there is state use of at least one nuclear weapon against another actor’s territory and/or forces, excluding non-state use of nuclear weapons.

P_and_Q.title: If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, will there be at least one fatality in India and will the first nuclear strike of the conflict occur between June and September?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, this question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:
a.) There is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in India, at any point between January 1, 2021, to January 1, 2030. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
b.) The first nuclear strike in the first nuclear conflict between January 1, 2021, to January 1, 2030, happens between June 1 and September 30 inclusive (of any year).

If there is no such fatality in India or if the first nuclear strike does not occur between June and September, this question will resolve as NO.

Definitions:
An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. A detonation will be considered "within" India if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in India's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

"Nuclear conflict" is defined as a situation in which there is state use of at least one nuclear weapon against another actor’s territory and/or forces. This state use could be deliberate, inadvertent, accidental, or unauthorised but by an actor in the state’s chain of command. This excludes non-state use of nuclear weapons.

P.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. (If there is no report about net emission levels in 2030, we should wait for one rather than resolving this question ambiguously.)
If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered

Q_given_P.title: Given that US greenhouse gas emissions are halved by 2030, will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. If this condition is met, then the question resolves YES if a geoengineering bill that is introduced in the House of Representatives and/or the Senate is subsequently enacted as legislation (by being signed by the U.S. president, or through other means) before or on 31/12/2024. For the purpose of this question, a geoengineering bill is any bill reported by the relevant Congress website search. This search involves the following terms: "Climate engineering" OR "geoengineering" OR "Solar radiation management" OR "Stratospheric Particle Injection" OR "Stratospheric aerosol injection" OR "Marine cloud brightening" OR "Ocean sulfur cycle enhancement". The question resolves NO if no such legislation is enacted by the end of 2024. If the initial condition of halved emissions is not met, the question resolves as N/A.

P_and_Q.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030 AND will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024?
P_and_Q.body:
This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: 

1. There is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. If there is no report about net emission levels in 2030, we should wait for one rather than resolving this question ambiguously. If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered.

2. A geoengineering bill that is introduced in the House of Representatives and/or the Senate is subsequently enacted as legislation (by being signed by the U.S. president, or through other means) before or on 31/12/2024. For the purpose of this question, a geoengineering bill is any bill reported by the relevant Congress website search. This search involves the following terms: "Climate engineering" OR "geoengineering" OR "Solar radiation management" OR "Stratospheric Particle Injection" OR "Stratospheric aerosol injection" OR "Marine cloud brightening" OR "Ocean sulfur cycle enhancement".

The question resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Donald Trump)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.
Fine Print
If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
Note: in the previous versions of this question, Donald Trump's question originally asked "If Trump is not sworn in as President in 2021, will he become the Republican nominee for President in 2024?"; please bear this in mind when interpreting the forecast history.

Q_given_P.title: Given that Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, will Taliban-controlled Afghanistan be used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if Donald Trump is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If Donald Trump is selected, then this question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met based on credible media reports by December 31, 2026: 1) A terrorist attack that kills at least 10 people has been conducted against a NATO nation, outside of Afghanistan. 2) This terrorist attack was carried out by a member of the Afghan Taliban, or a member of any terrorist organization funded, supported, or protected by the Afghan Taliban. The attack must be confirmed by the United States federal government, NATO, or the European Union. The question will resolve NO if these conditions are not met. An attack will be considered 'against a NATO nation' if it occurs within a NATO nation's internationally recognized borders, or is deliberately targeted towards a NATO nation's government facilities or personnel overseas (e.g., embassy or military base) outside of Afghanistan. A terrorist attack within a non-NATO nation that is not targeted at a NATO nation's government facility or personnel (e.g., an attack on a sports stadium in India that incidentally kills >10 NATO nationals) will not be sufficient to trigger a positive resolution. If the attacks result in the deaths of the attackers, such as in a suicide bombing, those deaths will not count towards the resolution criteria, even if the attackers are citizens of a NATO nation. What counts as a 'terrorist organization' will be determined by the US federal government, NATO, or the European Union. In the event that NATO ceases to exist by the resolution date, the question will resolve negatively if no such attack occurs prior to NATO's dissolution. Any terrorist attacks that occur while the Taliban are not in control of Afghanistan will not trigger a positive resolution. The Taliban will be considered in control of Afghanistan if they control either Kabul or a majority (18+ / 34) provincial capitals.

P_and_Q.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election AND will Taliban-controlled Afghanistan be used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met: 

1. Donald Trump is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this part of the question will resolve as Ambiguous. 

2. Afghanistan, under Taliban control, is used as a base for a terrorist attack that kills at least 10 people in a NATO nation by December 31, 2026. The attack must be conducted outside of Afghanistan by a member of the Afghan Taliban or a member of any terrorist organization funded, supported, or protected by the Afghan Taliban. The attack must be confirmed by credible media reports and determined by the United States federal government, NATO, or the European Union. 

The question will resolve NO if either of these conditions is not met. If NATO ceases to exist by the resolution date, the question will resolve negatively if no such attack occurs prior to NATO's dissolution. Any terrorist attacks that occur while the Taliban are not in control of Afghanistan will not trigger a positive resolution. The Taliban will be considered in control of Afghanistan if they control either Kabul or a majority (18+ / 34) provincial capitals.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (India)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Q_given_P.title: Given that there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: This question is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, the question will resolve as Ambiguous. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality in any country or area globally. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, so a fatality caused by things like fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not count towards a positive resolution. Neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be at least one fatality in India from an offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, and will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality globally by 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met:
1. There is at least one offensive nuclear detonation anywhere on Earth between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030, and there is at least one fatality in India from any such detonation. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions.
2. Before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality anywhere globally. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, and neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution.

If no offensive nuclear detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in the period from January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030, this question will resolve as NO. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of India and do not involve non-state actors, or if they are not offensive, this question will also resolve as NO.

Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" India if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in India's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.
Resolution criteria will be gathered from reliable news sources or from direct government or multi-national reports such as from the UN.

P.title: If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, will the company have performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as this Metaculus question.
If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves according to the following methodology:
Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known, as determined by the above Metaculus question. Let C be the company that developed the AGI.
Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive.[1]
Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists.
Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.
[1] In the event that the market is closed on the start/end date, instead use the latest prior date on which the market is open. In the event that the date does not exist, use the latest prior date that exists. For example, if the AGI is developed on December 31, "one month prior" is considered to be November 30. If the market is closed on November 30, then use November 29 instead

Q_given_P.title: Given that the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company and that company's stock has performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months, will the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company or if the company's stock has not performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months. If the conditions are met, then this question resolves YES if expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence, and NO otherwise. The resolution criteria for "weak" AGI includes the ability to pass a Turing test, score highly on the Winograd Schema Challenge, perform well on the SAT mathematics section, and learn and explore the game "Montezuma's revenge" effectively.

P_and_Q.title: If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, will the company have performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months AND will the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for the first part:
This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as this Metaculus question.
If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves according to the following methodology:
Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known, as determined by the above Metaculus question. Let C be the company that developed the AGI.
Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive.
Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists.
Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
If the first AGi is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.
Resolution Criteria for the second part:
The question will resolve as Yes if expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence.
For the purposes of this question, "weak" AGI will be defined as meeting the qualifications in this question, the terms of which are reproduced in the fine print below.
Fine Print
A "weak" Artificial General Intelligence should be capable of the following:
Able to reliably pass a Turing test of the type that would win the Loebner Silver Prize.
Able to score 90% or more on a robust version of the Winograd Schema Challenge, e.g. the "Winogrande" challenge or comparable data set for which human performance is at 90+%
Be able to score 75th percentile (as compared to the corresponding year's human students; this was a score of 600 in 2016) on all the full mathematics section of a circa-2015-2020 standard SAT exam, using just images of the exam pages and having less than ten SAT exams as part of the training data. (Training on other corpuses of math problems is fair game as long as they are arguably distinct from SAT exams.)
Be able to learn the classic Atari game "Montezuma's revenge" (based on just visual inputs and standard controls) and explore all 24 rooms based on the equivalent of less than 100 hours of real-time play (see closely-related question.)
By "unified" we mean that the system is integrated enough that it can, for example, explain its reasoning on an SAT problem or Winograd schema question, or verbally report its progress and identify objects during videogame play. (This is not really meant to be an additional capability of "introspection" so much as a provision that the system not simply be cobbled together as a set of sub-systems specialized to tasks like the above, but rather a single system applicable to many problems.)

P.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Donald Trump)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Fine Print
This question does not require that the individual winning the 2024 Election wins the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning the election, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that they have been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress.
In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

Q_given_P.title: Given that Donald Trump is elected as the US President in 2024, will the next US presidential election also be considered fraudulent by the losing party?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose Donald Trump wins the 2024 US presidential election, which is determined by the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or is selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment. This question resolves as follows:

- Resolves N/A if Donald Trump does not win the 2024 US presidential election.
- If Donald Trump wins, this question then resolves YES if ANY of the following conditions are met by the losing party:
  1. The losing candidate states that they consider the election result "fraudulent" or "rigged", or a very close synonym of those words, before the scheduled inauguration. The word choice must be confirmed as a close synonym by thesaurus.com and at least one moderator.
  2. The losing candidate refuses to concede two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting their opponent to win the election, and neither the AP nor Fox News have retracted their projection in that time.
  3. Fewer than 20% of congressional members of the losing party acknowledge their candidate's loss two weeks after both the AP and Fox News project the opposite-party candidate to win, and neither projection has been retracted.
  4. A survey from the Morning Consult reveals that fewer than 30% of survey participants who are members of the losing party state that the election was "probably" or "definitely" free and fair in the most recent such survey following projections from both the AP and Fox News.

- Resolves NO if none of the above conditions are met.

P_and_Q.title: Will Donald Trump be elected US President in 2024 AND will the next US presidential election be considered fraudulent by the losing party?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Donald Trump being elected: This question will resolve as Yes if Donald Trump wins the 2024 US presidential election, which means he wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or is selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment. This question does not require that the individual winning the 2024 Election wins the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning the election, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that they have been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress. In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for Donald Trump.

Resolution Criteria for the election being considered fraudulent: This question resolves positively if ANY of the following come true following the 2024 presidential election: 1) The losing candidate states that they consider the election result "fraudulent" or "rigged", or some very close synonym of those words, as determined by consensus in the comment section of this question. The losing candidate must make this claim before the scheduled inauguration. If there is a dispute as to whether the candidate did indeed say a close synonym of "fraudulent" or "rigged", and therefore a dispute over whether the word choice counts for positive resolution, then the following method of resolution will be used: if thesaurus.com lists "fraud", "fraudulent", or "rigged" as a synonym of the word, and at least one moderator agrees that it is a close synonym, then it counts for positive resolution. 2) The losing candidate refuses to concede two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting their opponent to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time. 3) Fewer than 20% of congressional members of the losing party believe that their candidate lost the election as determined by credible media two weeks following both the AP and Fox News projecting the opposite-party candidate to win the election AND neither the AP or Fox News having retracted their projection in that time. 4) A survey from the Morning Consult reveals that fewer than 30% of survey participants who are members of the losing party state that the election was "probably" or "definitely" free and fair in the most recent such survey following projections from both the AP and Fox News. Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.

This question will resolve as YES if both Donald Trump is elected US President in 2024 AND the next US presidential election is considered fraudulent by the losing party according to the above criteria. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the Eurozone collapse before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as "yes" if, at any time between December 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) formally closes, or the Euro is no longer the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency.
Fine Print
Edit: on April 17, 2022, clarified that "no longer the de facto primary currency" means for all three of Germany, France, and Italy, not just any one of those three.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the Eurozone collapses before 2030, if there are more than 100 nuclear detonations by 2050, will average global cereal yields be at least 5% lower in the following 5 years than in the previous 5 years?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves as N/A if the Eurozone does not collapse before 2030. If the Eurozone collapses before 2030, this question is conditional on there being 100 or more offensive nuclear detonations in a single conflict before January 1, 2050. If that condition isn't met, this question will resolve as ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if both conditions are met, and average global cereal yields over the 5 years following the end of the nuclear conflict that met the above condition are at least 5% lower than the average in the 5 years preceding the nuclear conflict. Crop yield data will be taken from the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (or another credible organization). Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days or less of a previous detonation (even if the detonations involve different state pairings, unrelated motivations, etc.). For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations of state or nonstate nuclear weapons. Note that crop yields are currently rising over time, so a 5% decline in the 5 years following the conflict compared to the 5 years before the conflict corresponds to a >5% decline compared to what would be expected under normal conditions. If a relevant source gives a relevant estimate but in the form of a range, this question can resolve positively as long as the midpoint of the range is 5% or higher. For simplicity, no attempt will be made to discern whether the decline in cereal yields was caused by the nuclear detonations. Detonations must occur less than 20 kilometers above the surface of the Earth in order to count as being "on or over territory owned by the US". This question will also resolve positively if the first nuclear conflict meeting the above-mentioned condition clearly causes more than this amount of decline in yields but also causes sufficient civilizational collapse that there are no or extremely few remaining credible sources on any topic. We request that you forecast your true beliefs despite the fact that a Metaculus score seems unlikely to be tracked or cared about in that scenario, given that forecasts on this question may play a role in informing important decisions. Detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions are not counted towards positive resolution. Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins. In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

P_and_Q.title: Will the Eurozone collapse before 2030 AND if there are >100 nuclear detonations by 2050, will average global cereal yields be at least 5% lower in the following 5 years than in the previous 5 years?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. At any time between December 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) formally closes, or the Euro is no longer the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency. 
2. There are 100 or more offensive nuclear detonations in a single conflict before January 1, 2050, and average global cereal yields over the 5 years following the end of the nuclear conflict that met that condition are at least 5% lower than the average in the 5 years preceding the nuclear conflict. Crop yield data will be taken from the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (or another credible organization). Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days or less of a previous detonation. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (US, UK, or France)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
